div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Boston Evening Transcript, February 26, 1910
div1.p:
Charles Brockden Brown, the Father of
Our Novelists, and His Lurid Stories

CHARLES BROCKDEN BROWN. the
Philadelphia novelist who died just
a hundred years since in the
city of his birth, has often
been called the “Father of the American
Novel” by persons who have never read
his tales. It is needless, at this late date,
to characterize his novels. They were, to
be sure, admired by readers both at home
and in the old country, where Shelley and
Mrs. Shelley both praised them with en-
thusiasm: they may even be counted on to
induce a pleasant shiver in the modern
reader. If he be not oversophisticated.
Their influence upon other story tellers, at
home and abroad, has, indeed, never been
very well worked out; though Richard
Henry Stoddard has not hesitated to call
Brown “Poe's master in prose.” If there
were any present intention of writing an
essay on Brockden Brown, it would be
worth while, perhaps, to explain that he
barked back, in a sense, to the “terror
school” founded by Horace Walpole, and
continued the work of that psychological
“shocker,” William Godwin. But it is not,
at present, a case of writing a literary
paper on Charles Brockden Brown. Let us
think of him as one who devoted himself,
in his novel-writing, to a period become, to-
day, very obscure. The interest of the
historian in his work is keen enough; so,
too, that of the amateur of American his-
tory. For Brown saw the melodramatic
advantages of that age when Young Amer-
ica was still in the grip of the Yellow Jack.
It was, in his hands, an age of many hor-
rors.

In another story. “Ormond.” Brown told
of Gotham's milder sufferings: in “Arthur
Mervyn”--his least forgotten fletion--be
chose for his grewsome background plague-
stricken Philadelphia. In those days it
was neither typhoid nor trolley strikes for
which the city was to be pitied; nor had
it yet won a reputation as the worst gov-
erened municipality. Yet “plague-stricken”
is no figure of rhetoric when it comes to
describing the Quaker City of 1793: so that
even thus early the prosperous and con-
tented town deserved something of her
neighbor's pity. The yellow fever epidemic
that the Federal capital of those days
passed through was far more terrible than
that of 1862, or of 1797: the attack was
more general than those from which New
York suffered in 1795 and 1798 and 1799,
and infinitely worse than any of New Lon-
don's; it was more terrifying, at least, and
far less intelligently handled than those
which threw into a frenzy the Southern
towns of Charleston, Memphis and New
Orleans, as late as the eighteen-fifties, and
-in the case of Memphis-1878. Terrifying
is indeed the word, however, for all these
plagues. In 1819, for example, the popula-
tion of Mobile fell, through deaths and
flight, from 1900 to 300. In the last serious
outbreak of the disease at that place, there
were more than 17,000 cases, and over five
thousand fatalities. This by way of pref-
ace to the best known passage in any of all
Brockden Brown's novels; a passage not,
however, so well known that one need
seriously apologize for reproducing it. It
makes real to us even statistics, statistics
make it even seem real. Here is the “Ar-
thur Mervyn” description of a yellow
fever hospital in Philadelphia-the de-
scription that leads Professor Barrett
Wendell to compare Brown with Defoe,
imaginative historian of London's plague-
year.

After a time I opened my eyes, and slow-
ly gained some knowledge of my situation.
I lay upon a mattress, whose condition
proved that a half-decayed corpse had re-
cently been dragged from it. The room was
large, but it was covered with beds like
my own. Between each, there was scarce-
ly the interval of three feet. Each sus-
tained a wretch, whose groans and distor-
tions bespoke the desperateness of his con-
dition.

You will scarcely believe that, in this
scene of horrors, the sound of laughter
should be overheard. While the upper
rooms of this building are filled with the
sick and the dying, the lower apartments
are the scenes of carousals and mirth. The
wretches who are hired, at enormous wages,
to tend the sick and convey away the dead,
neglect their duty and consume the cor-
dials, which are provided for the patients,
in debauchery and riot. A female visage,
bloated with malignity and drunkenness.
occasionally looked in. Dying eyes were
cast upon her, invoking the boon. perhaps.
of a drop of cold water, or her assistance
to change a posture which compelled him
to behold the ghastly writhings or dreadful
smile of his neighbor.

The visitant had left the banquet for a
moment, only to see who was dead. If she
entered the room. blinking eyes and reel-
ing steps showed her to be totally unquali-
fied for ministering the aid that was needed.
Presently she disappeared and others
ascended the staircase, a coffin was de-
posited at the door, the wretch, whose heart
still quivered, was seized by rude hands.
and dragged along the floor into the pas-
sage.

This piece of writing and others like it
won for Brockden Brown comparison, not
with Defoe alone, but also with Boccaccio.
In reading some pages of “Arthur Mer-
vyn” one is reminded, too, of the fact that
after Brown came Poe, the author of “The
Red Death.”

In recent years physicians have deter-
mined the precise manner in which yellow
fever is spread. Suspected long before, the
criminal complicity of the mosquito as an
agent of contagion was decisively demon-
started only after the Spanish-American
War. during the American occupation of
Cuba. Now that we understand the case.
the testimony of Latrobe's “Journal,” con-
tributed shortly before the outbreak of our
second war with Great Britain, has for us
a freshened interest. Writing in New Or-
leans, the architect and naturalist, whose
memoranda are so impressive a document
in Americans, notes that “as soon as the
sun sets the mosquitos appear in clouds,
and fill every room in the house, as well as
the open air. Their noise . . . fills the
air, and there is a character of occasional
depression and elevation in it, like that of a
concert of frogs in a marah. . . . When
(as was the case in Philadelphia) the city
shall be supplied with water by pipes the
evil may probably be considerably les-
sened.” The evil of mosquitos, that is; it
never occurs to Latrobe to associate recur-
rent epidemics of yellow fever with the
bites of the insects that annoy him so
And it is true that the disease was primari-
ly propagated, not by the home-grown
pests, but by those mosquitos imported on
vessels from the south. Still there is a
certain grim humor about Latrobe's writ-
ing:

I say nothing of the yellow fever, because
I believe this calamity may be moderated,
if not entirely eradicated, by a good medi-
cal police, and under a better understand-
ing of its origin and treatment than now
prevails at New Orleans.

How infinitely superior is the diarist's
tone, as he writes of these ignorant Louisi-
anians: Yet he himself was as much at sea
in the matter as they were themselves.
Referring to the yellow jack as an annual
visitor at Philadelphia, he blames it upon
the circumstance that clear water was to be
found “in every possible spot of ground.”
“Every house,” he ran on, “has its privy
and its drains, which . . . certainly con-
taminate the water of every pump in the
neighborhood.”

Unsanitary to a degree as that arrange-
ment was, we know, now, that it had little
-even nothing-to do with the recurring
plague. Quite as rational were the earlier
explanations of the New York and Philadel-
phia pestilences-explanations that blamed
itall-somewhat variously-upon the
“spoiled coffee and fish” dumped by a West
Indiaman, and left to poison the air of the
shipping quarter with its emanations (the
supposition mentioned in the “Journal of
Elizabeth Drinker”), the 'unfinished situa-
tion of the docks in Front street" (see
James Hardie's “Malignant Fever Lately
Prevalent.” etc.). and the heat of the sum-
mers preceding the more severe outbreaks,
followed by wet weather. The Philadelphia
Academy of Medicine attributed one of the
later outbreaks-that of 1798--to the exhal-
ations of the alleys, gutters, docks and
common sewers; to the foul air discharged
with the ballast of the ship Deborah, from
Hispaniola. etc. The origin of the disease
was in fine, unknown. All men were sure
of was its deadliness. The “general extinc-
tion of the disease by frost” was widely
recognized: what a pity that someone did
not connect the coming of the frost and the
killing off of the infected tropical mosqui-
tos: Temperance was alleged to be a safe-
guard against infection: so that the pesti-
lence lacked not its sunny side. The greater
cleanliness of European cities was cited as
the explanation of their comparative immu-
nity.

It is unfortunate that the ingenious La-
trobe never coupled mosquito and disease
in the relation of cause and effect-as he
did couple them as twin pests of New Or-
leans. But the insect was not as yet sus-
pected. It was Brockden Brown's privilege
to discover the literary possibilities of Phil-
adelphia suffering from plague; it was our
privilege-or that of our heroic army-sur-
geons-to attack the evil scientifically.
